awd_titl_txt: STEM Honors, Study Abroad, and Scholars Programs (STEM HSASP)
awd_abstract_narration:
Galveston College, a Hispanic Serving community college, will improve educational opportunities for low-income, academically talented students by creating a new honors program, a new study abroad program, and a new scholar's program to support STEM majors from their first year through transfer to a four-year institution. The honors program will develop academic and nonacademic skills using curricular and co-curricular initiatives, to increase student success at Galveston College and after transfer to a four-year institution. The study abroad program, with opportunities typically not available to STEM community college students, will to develop students into a more globally literate STEM workforce. The S-STEM Scholars at Galveston College will financially support 52 students for two years. 

To study the impact of the Honors, Study Abroad, and Scholars Programs, a mixed method research and evaluation approach will be employed. The investigators will measure a number of variables including financial support, workload, and participation in co-curricular activities. This approach will allow the investigators to make evidence-based improvements to better achieve, sustain, and share successes. The programs are designed to (1) broaden participation in STEM fields at the community college level; (2) be sustainable at Galveston College; and (3) be replicable at similar institutions.

por.por_cntn:
Galveston College (GC), a designated Hispanic Serving 2-year institution, received an NSF Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) award to support the S-STEM project titled, Building our Potential: A STEM Honors and Scholars Initiative at a Hispanic-Serving Community College (Award No. 1565155, 2016-2021).

The goals of the Galveston College S-STEM project were to (1) increase the recruitment, retention, student success, and graduation or transfer of low-income academically talented students with demonstrated financial need who are pursuing an associate of science degree with a STEM emphasis at GC; (2) enhance, adopt, and study curricular, co-curricular, and institutional activities and initiatives that support Goal 1; and (3) contribute to the adoption and sustainability of those activities and initiatives found to be effective for low-income academically talented students at GC. Galveston College successfully accomplished these goals.

Outcomes relevant to Goal 1 include 69 students awarded an NSF Scholarship, a 52% increase in the number of students enrolled in STEM degree programs (95 in 2016 to 145 in 2020); a 55.0% transfer rate by GC STEM students compared to a 12.1% transfer rate for the college overall (fall terms of 2016, 2017, and 2018 combined); a four-fold increase in the number of STEM students completing an Associate of Science degree in STEM (5 in 2016 to 21 in 2019); and an average GPA of 3.4 among the NSF Scholarship recipients compared to an average GPA of 2.6 among all STEM students. Outcomes relevant to Goal 2 include establishing a successful and sustainable STEM Honors Program at GC which supports co-curricular activities such as undergraduate research experiences; establishing a successful and sustainable STEM study abroad program at GC; strengthening the collaboration and professionalism among STEM faculty through professional development and training relevant to student mentoring and supporting undergraduate research experiences; and strengthening and expanding collaboration and partnerships among academia with our University Transfer partners. Outcomes relevant to Goal 3 include active participation by Galveston College in regional and state-wide efforts to disseminate and share lessons learned from the S-STEM project with other institutions and organizations (e.g., Texas Association of Community Colleges’ Texas Pathways project and University of Houston System’s Guided Pathways to Success project).

Intellectual Merit. Knowledge has been advanced in understanding structure and policy for a new STEM Honors program; for supporting STEM faculty as mentors; for a new study abroad program; for utilizing a DBIR model in evaluation; and advancing an understanding of students’ barriers and motivations for participation in STEM programs. Broader Impacts encompasses the potential to benefit society. This project has expanded participation of low-income and underrepresented minority students in STEM programs, facilitating students’ transfer goals, and contributing to increased participation by these students in STEM Bachelor of Science programs at regional universities.

 


Last Modified: 10/29/2021
Modified by: Sandra Metoyer
